At that time, the west suddenly became radiant like the light of the sun. Venerable Ä€nanda, who had not yet escaped desire, said:
World-Honored One!
What is the significance of this light?
The Buddha said:
Ä€nanda!
This is the son of Black Fragrance, the most excellent one among the five-supernatural-powers sages, named Vipula.

He was emaciated from fasting and his body lacked luster. He was accompanied by five hundred people who practiced austerities together with him, namely the ascetics Abha, Devarshi, Sampanna, Dantanna, Kamana, Mekhanasa, Samkhya, and Udraka. They surrounded him in front and back as they came to where I was.
At that time, the ascetic Vipashyin saw from afar the World-Honored One, whose body and mind were tranquil, dwelling in the forest, attended by the bhikshus.
He then thought to himself:
How extraordinary and noble!

The abode of omniscience is endowed with perfect form and appearance. He abandoned the position of a wheel-turning king and sixty thousand colorful women as if discarding poisonous food. He practiced austerities in the mountains and forests, away from all desires and pleasures. His fame is heard everywhere. It is truly not false.
At that time, there was an ascetic in the assembly named Narada. He looked at the Tathagata from afar and felt joy in his heart. He then spoke a verse, saying:
Looking at that blue-flowered tree grove below, who is that person, like a mass of purple gold?
The wonderful jewels of Mount Sumeru flow with light, like the autumn moon without any obstruction.
At that time, the sages were all delighted, joined palms in respect, and gradually approached the Buddha.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:

You all observe those sages in JambudvÄ«pa, with disheveled hair, dwelling in the wilderness, smearing ashes, fasting on the half-month and monthly observance days, emaciated, wearing deer and tree bark as clothing, not trimming hair and nails, squatting in the open air.
Some are the color of black smoke, bees, or charcoal, using spells and fire sacrifices as auspicious, dwelling in empty places, under trees, wherever they may be.
Some jump off high cliffs or into deep waters, scorching their bodies with blazing fire and the sun, relying on their lineage to depart from the unsurpassed wisdom.
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that these sages see impurity, are attached to various existences, revolve in birth and death, and are unable to escape.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us, having heard the World-Honored Buddha speak thus, said in unison:
We, now, relying on the TathÄgata, diligently cultivate the holy life, and in all existences, will forever escape.
At that time, the sage Vipula, together with his companions, gradually arrived before the Buddha. Seeing the arhats' majestic virtue and dignity, he inwardly felt awe, bent his body, and looked down.

Each had their hair disheveled, wore a white rope around their body, had a dark complexion, yellow-green eyes, dry hair, held three pieces of wood, and their bodies were lowly and ugly, either walking in the sky,
or discussing worldly classics, they arrived before the TathÄgata and said:
World-Honored One!
Now this assembly, may the Buddha know the time.
The Buddha said:
Vipula!
I have already understood the various births and their inherent nature.
At that time, Ä€nanda said:
World-Honored One!
Who is this sage surrounded by a crowd, eloquent and intelligent, with his hair standing on end?
The Buddha said:
Ä€nanda!
This is Brhaspati, who composes the Vedas, upholds and practices the teachings of Åšakra, and creates various worldly texts.
At that time, the arhats said to each other:
What has this sage attained, practicing austerities like this, yet not liberated from birth and death?
They further thought:
This crowd of sages is now coming to the Buddha. What will they ask?
Will it be about causes and conditions?
Or about selflessness?
At that time, the sage Brhaspati joined his palms towards the Buddha and said:
World-Honored One!
The appearance of a Buddha is difficult, and so is a gathering of the assembly.
I now have a few questions. Please have compassion and explain them for me.
The Buddha said:
Great sage!
Ask as you wish, and I will explain for you.
The sage ViÅ›vÄmitra said:ğŸ”½What is giving?
What is the meaning of giving?
Who is a donor?
What is the meaning of donor?ğŸ”½Why is one who gives not called a donor?
Why is a donor not called one who gives?
How does giving to a recipient result in obtaining the rewards of merit?
How is it that after giving, whether in the present life or after death, the merit of giving follows one's actions and accumulates?
World-Honored One!
After the TathÄgata's nirvÄá¹‡a, who receives the offerings made to stÅ«pas and gains the rewards of merit?
The Buddha said:
Great sage!
What you have asked is extremely rare, in order to awaken those who have newly given rise to the intention.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra was in the assembly, with white hair and wrinkled face. He raised his eyebrows with his right hand and looked around for a long time, saying:
I have heard that the sage ViÅ›vÄmitra is praised by the world. Why does he now ask about giving like a young child, not knowing?
Why does he not ask about the profound truth of the absence of self, but rather about the fruits of giving?
The Venerable Ä€nanda then bowed at the Buddha's feet and said:
World-Honored One!
That sage is attached to giving. I wish to explain the meaning of giving for him.
The Buddha said:
Ä€nanda!
If a disciple answers a question asked to the TathÄgata, it is not the teaching of the TathÄgata.
Then ÅšÄriputra again said to the Buddha:
Now this sage has various doubts. I wish to explain them.
The Buddha said:
No, it is not so.ğŸ”½

You are the foremost among the Å›rÄvakas. If you explain something in front of me that causes sentient beings to fall into evil destinies, slandering the TathÄgata as not having definitive knowledge, or saying that the TathÄgata's enlightened nature is still accompanied by conceit,
At that time, the bhiká¹£us, having heard the World-Honored Buddha speak thus, gave rise to pure faith and said:
World-Honored One!
The sage Vipula has questions he wishes to ask. Please resolve them for him.
At that time, the Buddha told the sage Vipula:
Listen attentively now to the fruits and retributions of giving and the distinctions in karmic actions.
If the recipients can cause the donors to give rise to fruits and retributions, this is the meaning of giving.

If there are sentient beings who give rise to a pure mind and use their own wealth and treasures to have their attendants give according to what is given, the master of those wealth and treasures is called the donor, and the attendant is called the giver.
If a person himself gives his own pure-hearted offerings, he becomes a benefactor and is also called a giver.
Furthermore, Great Sage!
Listen attentively to the thirty-two kinds of impure giving.
If a person gives with inverted views, it is not called pure giving.ğŸ”½Giving out of gratitude is not called pure giving.
Lacking compassion is not called pure giving.
Giving out of desire for form is not called pure giving.ğŸ”½Giving into fire is not called pure giving.
Throwing into water is not called pure giving.
Giving out of fear is not called pure giving.
Giving to the five kinds of families is not called pure giving.
Giving poison is not called pure giving.ğŸ”½Giving knives and sticks is not called pure giving.
Giving for the purpose of killing is not called pure giving.ğŸ”½Giving for the purpose of subduing others is not called pure giving.
Giving for the sake of praise is not called pure giving.
Giving to entertainers is not considered pure giving.ğŸ”½Giving to fortune-tellers is not considered pure giving.
Giving to those seeking adornments is not considered pure giving.
Making friends through giving is not considered pure giving.
If one is not delighted when birds and animals come to eat in one's courtyard, it is not considered pure giving.
Giving to those learning crafts is not considered pure giving.
Giving to doctors out of illness is not considered pure giving.
Giving wealth after first beating and scolding is not considered pure giving.
If one has doubts, thinking Is there a reward for giving now or not?
Such giving is not considered pure giving.

If after giving, one inwardly feels distressed, stingy, regretful, and resentful, it is not considered pure giving.ğŸ”½If one says, The recipient will later become my livestock, it is not considered pure giving.
If one says, I myself will receive the rewards of blessings, it is not considered pure giving.

If a person lacks pure faith in their youth, and later encounters illness and suffering or is on the verge of death, with excruciating pain in their body and limbs disintegrating, the messengers of Yama taunting them in front, and relatives weeping and looking at each other in grief throughout their life, if they only give at such a time, it is not considered pure giving.
If they think, Let other cities know that I am giving, it is not considered pure giving.

If they give with an inflated sense of jealousy, it is not considered pure giving.ğŸ”½If they hold gold, silver, silk, and other garments and give them with the hope of marrying into a wealthy and noble family, it is not considered pure giving.
If they give with the hope of obtaining a son, daughter, or other miscellaneous conditions, it is not considered pure giving.
If they think, I am giving now, and will receive the rewards in the future, it is not considered pure giving.
If they see the poor and do not feel compassion, but instead take their money and wealth to give to the wealthy and noble, it is not considered pure giving.
Or if one gives flowers and fruits out of greed, it is not considered a pure offering.
Good man!
These thirty-two kinds of defiled giving are like a person carrying seeds to a barren field and planting them as they wish.
However, those seeds rely on the great earth element, meet the moisture of heavenly rain, and will definitely sprout, up to flowering and fruiting, with little harvest.
At that time, the sage Vipashyin again said to the Buddha:
How can giving to those who uphold precepts and those who violate precepts not be destroyed?
The Buddha said:
Great sage!

If a person has pure faith in cause and effect, gives rise to a joyful mind, has no regrets or stinginess for sentient beings, and does not discriminate between those who uphold precepts and those who violate precepts,
Furthermore, good man!
There are five kinds of giving called great giving.
What are the five?
First, timely giving; second, to those practicing the Way; third, to the sick and their caregivers; fourth, to those expounding the Dharma; fifth, to those going to other countries.
There are also five kinds:
First, giving of the Dharma; second, giving of food; third, providing shelter; fourth, giving of lamps; fifth, giving of incense and flowers.

What is pure?
The Buddha said:
If one gives with a faithful mind, inwardly harboring compassion for sentient beings, dedicating it to enlightenment and universal pure liberation, it becomes pure.
There are also five unsurpassed kinds of giving.
What are the five?
First, giving to the TathÄgata is unsurpassed giving;
second, giving to the Saá¹…gha is unsurpassed giving;
third, giving to those expounding the Dharma is unsurpassed giving;ğŸ”½fourth, giving to one's father is unsurpassed giving;
fifth, giving to one's mother is unsurpassed giving.
There are also givers called great givers, namely, a king who has lost his position is called a great giver.
If one gives to those who are oppressed by the county government and have no one to rely on, and to those who are afflicted by illness and pain, it is called a great giving.
If one is abandoned by the king and is about to be executed, or if one's life is in danger, to give up one's own life to save the life of another is called a great giving.
Or to give medicine to those who are sick is also called a great giving.
Or to give to the Saá¹…gha of fully ordained monks at the proper time is also called a great giving.
Or to give to those who seek wisdom is also called a great giving.
Or to give to the class of animals, such as frogs, leeches, crows, and other birds and beasts, is also called a great giving.
Or to give to the needy so that they may be satisfied is also called a great giving.
If there are people who encourage others to give pure gifts and rejoice in them, it is also called a great giving.
Furthermore, Great Sage!
You asked me before, after my nirvana, how to plant and obtain the rewards of blessings.
Good man!
All Tathagatas are Dharma bodies, not form bodies. Whether in the world or after nirvana, the blessings of offerings are no different.
Like a wheel-turning king proclaiming on the great earth:
'In my kingdom, no one should kill living beings or speak falsely.'
Although the people of that country have not yet seen the king or attended him, they will simply follow the decree. The king will be delighted with these people.
Because of the king's prohibition against killing, these people will attain rebirth in the heavens. Those who violate it will fall into evil destinies.
Thus, great sage!
Although there are sentient beings who see my form body, if they do not protect their precepts, what can they gain?
Like Devadatta, although he encountered me, he still fell into hell.
If there are people in the future who diligently cultivate my teachings, they will be as rare as seeing my body, no different.
Furthermore, Great Sage!
As you have asked, the causes and conditions of blessings and virtues are accumulated.
Just as when burning reeds and bamboos, the flames that emerge cannot be said to be accumulated or aggregated.
In the same way, the donor accumulates provisions like a shadow following a form, but no one can see it.
It is also like grapes and sugarcane, which cannot be seen before pressing, and no one can see the accumulation of juice in one or two sections. However, the juice is not obtained from the outside.
The fruits of blessings and virtues are also like this. They are not in the donor's hands, heart, or body, but are not separate from them.
It is also like the seeds of a ficus tree, which cannot be seen when they are not yet ripe.
It is like a merchant who takes a small amount of goods to a big city, trades them widely, and obtains a lot of wealth.
Meritorious rewards are also like this. It is like a bee collecting flowers without damaging their color.
Who can measure the accumulation of clouds and rain?
In their production, they must be accomplished by themselves.
At that time, the sage Vipashyin said:
World-Honored One!
I have already understood the distinctions in giving.
How does this consciousness abide in the body and become attached to something?
The Buddha said:
Great sage!

It is like a king dwelling in a city. Fearing the coming of other armies, he preemptively digs moats, accumulates grain and provisions, raises soldiers, sets up banners and flags, trains and tames intoxicated elephants, strictly warns the troops, proclaims to be on alert, dons armor, focuses his thoughts on battle, and holds sharp weapons with exposed blades.
When the king's blessings are exhausted, the other armies become strong and eventually destroy him.

In this way, the king of consciousness resides in the city of the body, seeing that the six sense bases are constantly being harmed, piercing the moat of faith, wearing the armor of right mindfulness, riding the intoxicated Dharma elephant, and taming the mind-horse. It tells the six sense bases:
Now, the army of impermanence is coming. You should quickly put on the armor of giving, hold the sword of wisdom, prepare the crossbow of shame and conscience, and secure the embankment of precepts.

At that time, the six sense bases were gradually being pressed by the army of impermanence. At that time, that consciousness, like a king whose merits have been exhausted, abandoned the city and fled to another city-state to reside.
The sage Vipashyin again addressed the Buddha, saying:
How can I know which is the city of merit and which is not the city of merit that I should abandon?
The Buddha said:
Great sage!
It is like a person riding a large ship on the ocean, when suddenly encountering wind and waves churning and tossing, with sea turtles, whales, and giant sea creatures posing various dangers.
This person, relying on the boat, finally reaches the other shore. Having attained fearlessness, he circles the boat three times, respectfully makes offerings, and proclaims:
'Excellent!
By this boat, I have been able to cross the great ocean.'
Thus, great sage!
Those with blessings, when their lives end, think like this:
'Now, this body of mine will go to the good destinies and heavens, and the human body obtained will not be wasted.
Relying on this body-boat, I will cross the ocean of evil destinies. Excellent! The previous lives are very respectable.'
If there are people who fall into evil destinies, it is like crossing the ocean in a rotten boat. In the great ocean, they may sink or float, swaying and overturning.
Although this person's remaining life reaches the shore, he encounters lions, tigers, and wolves filling the place, scolding and saying:
'Alas!
This rotten old boat goes against the great ocean, causing me to be frightened and see such suffering.'
The consciousness that falls into evil destinies is also like this, scolding the body:
'I have been nurturing this disciple, but he has met with this evil retribution.
For a long time in the world, I have carried filthy grass, like a silkworm making a cocoon, only binding myself.
How can I allow myself to sink and drown like this?'
At that time, that consciousness, having just stayed in the mother's womb in the second body, in seven days was able to think like this:
'I have come to be born here from that cessation.'
Due to wholesome karma, the mind is joyful, able to cause the mother to have three kinds of characteristics.

Namely, the mother's face is serene, her countenance is upright, she has no blemishes, she presses the ground with her right foot, twice as heavy as usual, and she often uses her hand to rub her right side, wearing a white garment, increasing her beauty.
The consciousness that creates evil karma also thinks like this in seven days:
'I once committed such-and-such a crime in such-and-such a city.'

Having had this thought, he gives rise to sorrow, causing his mother to manifest various evil signs, namely, her body becomes foul-smelling, emaciated, withered and yellow, she is always sorrowful and frequently vomits, misfortunes fill the door, calamities and difficulties oppress her, and she suffers from many illnesses.

World-Honored One!

Having had this thought, it gives rise to a mind of disgust and says:
'Alas!
In this world, birth and death are enough. I sincerely wish to end all toilsome existences forever.

World-Honored One!

That consciousness has no characteristic of transcendence, and it is impossible to attain liberation.

If it were not so, then all those who cultivate merit and commit offenses would all be heading towards nirvana.
As you say, the consciousness that contemplates is the superior power of consciousness, not the superior power of wisdom.
Why is it so?
Consciousness can discriminate, while wisdom can understand. The combination of consciousness and wisdom is as you have said.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:

And the wisdom together with the foolishness.

Drawn by consciousness.

The liver, stomach, and various combinations form the body, which is established as a provisional entity.
The king of consciousness resides within it, but the body is not the controller.
Understanding the nature of all entities is called the union of wisdom and consciousness.

This consciousness is subtle and cannot be seen with the eyes. It has no faculties and is also inseparable.
If there is any timidity or fear in men, or if they give rise to discursive thoughts, it is all due to the dominance of consciousness, not the function of wisdom.
At that time, the sage Vipashyin again said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
How does one observe all sentient beings who come to be born from the realm of hell, up to those who come to be born from the human realm?
What are the differences in karma that lead to birth as a god, human, animal, hungry ghost, or in hell?
The Buddha said:
Great Sage!

The fundamental nature of sentient beings is to be born here and there, which is the realm of the Buddha, not something that the five supernormal powers and sages can know, nor is it something that devas, humans, MÄras, BrahmÄs, the highest of the highest gods, and other Å›rÄvakas can understand.

Listen attentively!

If there are sentient beings who firmly accomplish giving incense and flower garlands, this person will certainly be born in the Heaven of Holding Garlands.

At the time of death, the body emits a wonderful fragrance and fresh flowers appear. Their lifespan is two hundred years in the heavens. When they are about to die, there are two kinds of signs:ğŸ”½The leaves of the tree they inhabit wither and the branches droop down, and the fragrant flowers naturally disappear;

At that time, the heavenly maidens, seeing these signs of decline, surround him and wail, lamenting:
Alas!
Why is impermanence so merciless? Now, to those we cherish, it restricts us and does not allow us to stay. It will abandon us in an instant.

At that time, the heavenly son gradually becomes afflicted by a hot illness. Flames appear all over his body, but he is not tormented by the flames. His mind is still joyful. He then passes away from there and is reborn in the human realm, in the womb. He causes his mother to love fragrant flowers, garlands, and various fruits.
Moreover, in dreams they always see cities, towns, and marketplaces adorned everywhere with hanging flower garlands.

After being born, their appearance is radiant, they wear white clothes and flower garlands, are always cherished, enjoy visiting relatives, are attached to sensual pleasures, are emotionally attached to women, come and go lightly, are greedy for fine clothes, upper garments, and gardens and forests, and are overjoyed to see the wealthy and noble.
Furthermore, Great Sage!

Those who are heading towards the realm of the Four Heavenly Kings, if there are sentient beings who, with a compassionate mind, give clothes and food to the poor, provide medicine to the sick, build wells and springs, or give ponds and pools,

when those people are about to die, their bodies do not become emaciated, their complexions do not change, their bodies do not sweat, their voices are not hoarse, they do not defecate or urinate, they are fully satisfied by the six sense objects and their faculties are unimpaired, and they are able to see themselves among the heavenly multitudes.
After the life ends, the body is like a red lotus, with a wonderful fragrance coming from the mouth, and a cool breeze blowing the fragrance of wonderful flowers to touch the corpse.
Then that consciousness sees the four heavenly realms, with the parents joyfully indulging in desire.
At that time, the heavenly father rubs the heavenly mother's back with his right hand, and thus receives conception in the mother's thigh.
After seven days, he is born, fully endowed with heavenly adornments.

Great Sage, you should know that the land inhabited by the Four Heavenly Kings is eighty-four thousand yojanas long and wide, decorated with alternating gold, silver, yellow, and red, filled with hundreds of thousands of heavenly maidens, and with hundreds of thousands of flowers and fruits shaped like human forms.
In those gardens, the light of heavenly maá¹‡i jewels always shines, with tree branches and trunks hanging with kapok cloth and fine silks, the trees are smooth and delightful to see.
In those chambers, musical instruments are always suspended, and flutes and other instruments naturally emit sounds.
The celestial children there take food as their strength, fragrant and delicious, with red-colored rice that tastes like nectar.
Their eating vessels are of two kinds:
one is golden vessels, the other is silver vessels;
the colors, fragrances, and flavors they desire all appear in them.
There is also a heavenly drink called flower wine, fragrant and cool, extraordinary. If one smells it, one will naturally become intoxicated.

Those heavenly beings each have sleeping palaces called early autumn, draped with flower garlands, with golden, silver, and various precious sÄla trees, hundreds of thousands of them covering above. There are also various kinds of bedding and seating.

Sixty thousand heavenly maidens, with exceptionally beautiful faces and radiant clothing, their voices clear and bright in harmony with heavenly music, created by the gods of desire, singing, dancing, performing, laughing and joking, able to make those who see them increase their lustful desires.
In front of the palace, a pillar was planted, inlaid with gold and silver, adorned with colorful silks, and hung with precious banners swaying in the wind.
There were four heavenly kings:
The first was Dhá¹›tarÄá¹£á¹­ra, the second was VirÅ«á¸haka, the third was VirÅ«pÄká¹£a, and the fourth was VaiÅ›ravaá¹‡a.
These four heavenly kings, in that heavenly realm, sang, danced, feasted, and played to their heart's content.

At that time, among the assembly, the celestial youths, with extraordinary strength and skills, possessing the sublime bodies of the gods, stretched out their arms as they came and went, like intoxicated elephants, their bodies exuding a rich fragrance that permeated an entire yojana.
Their lifespans were five hundred years in the heavens, and none died prematurely.

The gardens, groves, and trees were resplendent and radiant, adorned with kaá¹­ambaka flowers, all fragrant and free from foul odors. The stairways on the four sides were made of various treasures. Hundreds of thousands of celestial maidens always sang and played music. The precious vessels emitted wonderful sounds.
